He signed a three-year deal with the club, succeeding Allan Johnston who left in early February. Locke, aged 41, will address the media at a press conference on Friday.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, is in conflict with Seminole County Elementary School over her use of essential oils on her five-year-old autistic son, Logan. Kemp applies these oils, which include scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, to help Logan stay calm and focused. The school threatened to suspend Logan due to complaints about the scent being a distraction to other students. Despite receiving a letter from the school board indicating the oils caused issues, Kemp plans to continue using them, emphasizing their positive impact on her son. The Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend Logan, recognizing the situation as a health issue.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, known as the Sandpiper Complex, was destroyed by a massive fire on Wednesday at 3 PM. The fire, which spread through 90 condos, was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings and could be seen from three miles away. Despite the efforts of 12 fire crews, the building eventually collapsed. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with claims suggesting it might have started near a parked car. The complex, used as a holiday home between May and November, suffered total loss, including personal belongings of the residents.

The Queen, approaching her 89th birthday, was seen riding her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, through Windsor Great Park without a helmet, as is her custom. She has a lifelong passion for horses, starting with a Shetland pony named Peggy at age four. Despite a knee injury that has reduced her riding time and led her to stop presiding over Trooping the Colour on horseback, she remains an avid equestrienne and breeder of several horse and pony breeds, including Fell and Highland ponies. The Fell pony, known for its docility and hardiness, has a rich history dating back to the Neolithic period and has been used for various purposes, from pack animals to riding horses, making it a favored breed by the Queen.

A dispute over noise levels between two Brisbane neighbors resulted in the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman, allegedly caused by a single punch from 28-year-old Phillip Pama. The incident occurred when Yeaman was making noise in his yard late at night, disturbing Pama, who works night shifts and was sleeping. Pama confronted Yeaman, leading to an altercation where Pama punched Yeaman in the head. Pama, described as a non-violent family man, was granted conditional bail and is awaiting further court proceedings. Neighbors and friends of Yeaman described him as kind but also noted his tendency to play loud music and his struggles with schizophrenia.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, sought to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the crime. Police conducted a sting operation, using an undercover officer posing as a hitman to catch Simonova on camera discussing her plans, which included breaking the teenager's limbs and causing him to bleed out. After handing over part of the payment, Simonova was arrested and now faces up to 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder. Vanya, who ended the relationship to be with a classmate, expressed relief and hoped for a severe punishment for Simonova.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, shares insights into his personal life, including his faith and family. He prays daily but does not discuss football with God or his wife. Mourinho emphasizes separating his professional and family life, noting his family's experience with poverty and their work with the World Food Programme. Despite his public persona, he considers himself a good person and family man. He occasionally faces professional challenges, such as a fine for criticizing match decisions, but maintains a balanced view of his life beyond football.

Bob Barker, the longtime host of "The Price Is Right," made a surprise return to the show on April 1, 2015, for the first time in eight years. At 91 years old, Barker, who hosted the show for 35 years until 2007, seamlessly took over the opening segment, "Lucky Seven," before handing the hosting duties back to current host Drew Carey. Despite his long absence, Barker's performance was as smooth as ever.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. around midnight on Friday for attempting to break into a house and destroying property. He faces felony charges and has been placed on leave with his security clearance revoked. Baldwin works in the Foreign Missions Branch, which supports U.S. diplomatic activities. His arrest follows another recent incident where a high-ranking supervisor was placed on leave due to misconduct allegations, both incidents currently under investigation by the Department of Homeland Security's Inspector General. These events add to the agency's recent troubles, including an incident in March involving high-ranking officials driving into a secure White House area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to take close-up photos of a hungry lion at a safari park. He left his car and approached the lion to within 10 feet, lying on the ground to capture the shots. The lion became aware of Saeed due to the camera's shutter sound, causing him to quickly retreat to his car as the lion jumped towards him. Saeed reflects that while he found the experience exhilarating at the time, he doubts he would repeat it given the danger.

The New York City Police have released an image of a distinctive tattoo in an effort to identify a woman who died on a Brooklyn street on March 22. The woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend, and could not be revived by paramedics. She had no identification but possessed a tattoo featuring the name "Monique" within a heart and topped with a rose on her right leg. The cause of death is still pending from the medical examiner’s report. The public is encouraged to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers with any information.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple, built a sustainable home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK due to financial constraints. Over a year and a half, they constructed a two-bedroom, wood and steel home that is primarily solar-powered, allowing them to live almost self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand. The home includes a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and draws water from a nearby spring. The total cost of the project was approximately $25,000, and the couple is very satisfied with their unique living space.

A study by Courtney Blackwell from Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who share iPads in class significantly outperformed their peers in early literacy tests. The shared iPad group scored about 30 points higher compared to students who used iPads individually or did not use them at all. This research, involving 352 students, suggests that collaborative learning around the technology is key to its effectiveness. Blackwell recommends that schools reconsider how they use tablets, particularly in early grades, to maximize educational benefits. Despite these findings, the general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers remains skeptical about using technology as a teaching aid outside of IT classes.

A two-legged piglet from Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation. Born without hind legs, the piglet learned to walk and balance on its front legs, as shown in a heartwarming video that gained widespread attention. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," forages for food, mixes with its fully-legged siblings, and has attracted many visitors from nearby villages. Farmer Ms. Duan, the owner, discovered the unique piglet shortly after its birth. This case is reminiscent of another instance in China where a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became famous for walking on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dale Coyne Racing, was injured when struck by Francesco Dracone's car on lap 25. Dracone, who was exiting his pit box, spun and clipped Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches at the infield care center and was released. The accident occurred under wet conditions, which affected traction for many drivers. Dracone did not finish the race and placed 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The attack, captured on CCTV, shows Severiano dragging de Sena's body into their garden, slamming her head into the concrete 11 times, and punching her face 10 times. He then shot her five times at point-blank range. Severiano confessed to the crime, citing jealousy over men looking at his wife as the motive. De Sena, known by her stage name Amanda Bueno, was a member of the dance group Jaula das Gostozuedas. Neighbors reported hearing an argument and gunshots shortly after the newlywed couple's marriage. Severiano attempted to flee in a stolen car but crashed and was apprehended by the police, who found multiple weapons and a bulletproof vest in the vehicle. He faces a potential life sentence for the murder.

Sarah Wilson, a 41-year-old journalist and author, has publicly discussed her struggle with mental illness, which nearly led her to suicide. Her anxiety, compounded by thyroid disease, lack of close family ties, and feelings of isolation, made her feel there was no point in continuing her life. She highlights the link between anxiety and depression, noting that anxiety is becoming increasingly prevalent among Australian women, with one in three expected to experience it in their lifetime. Despite her past struggles, Wilson has found some peace and emphasizes the importance of acknowledging the connection between anxiety and depression to effectively address these issues.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was initially charged with second-degree assault for beating her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. The incident occurred when Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom and asked her to leave, which led to the assault. Prosecutors later dropped the charges, deeming Curtin's actions "completely justified" under Oregon law, which permits the use of force against intruders refusing to leave a residence. Curtin's defense highlighted the ex-girlfriend's history of harassment and attempts to sabotage Curtin’s relationship. If convicted, Curtin could have faced nearly six years in prison. Since the incident, Curtin has given birth and moved on with her life, while the boyfriend has distanced himself from both women and their children.

Gemma, a pit bull from California, was caught on film reacting negatively to a piece of broccoli mixed in with her treats. Her owner attempted to trick her into eating the vegetable, but Gemma showed clear disgust, spitting the broccoli out on the floor. The video highlights Gemma's strong dislike for the vegetable, contrasting with her enjoyment of treats, sleeping, and spending time with her human family. The passage humorously notes that the two children living with Gemma should not emulate her behavior regarding healthy eating.

HSBC issued an apology after a link on its official website redirected visitors to a pornographic site. This occurred when the URL for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which were discontinued in 2011, was allowed to expire and was subsequently taken over by a pornographic business. HSBC promptly removed the hyperlink upon discovering the issue and assured the public that its website remains secure. The bank also stated it has no association with the external site and apologized for any inconvenience caused.

A 13-year-old boy from Maryland, Marcus, and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in their second-floor bedroom when a fire broke out on the first floor of their home in Clinton. Marcus called 911, remained calm during the 11-minute call, and provided detailed instructions to the dispatcher. He also comforted his sister, who was distressed. Prince George's County firefighters rescued the siblings by breaking a window and entering the room. Firefighter Lt. Kenny Ward handed Marcus out the window and gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other three family members escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae have been lighting up Australia's east coast, notably in Jervis Bay, South Coast of NSW, creating a stunning neon glow. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the phenomenon as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of luminescent plankton. A similar event occurred at Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers, an oceanography expert from the University of New South Wales, explained that the glow is produced by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn, typically due to natural causes. The luminescence serves as a defense mechanism for this carnivorous cell, which feeds on diatoms.

New genetic tests, such as EndoPredict, can identify specific markers in breast tumors to assess the risk of cancer recurrence after surgery. These tests help determine if chemotherapy is necessary by evaluating the aggressiveness of the tumor. For many women, the tests can show a low risk of recurrence (as low as 5%), making chemotherapy potentially unnecessary and avoiding its severe side effects. Currently, these tests are mostly available privately, costing around £2,500, but there is hope for NHS availability. Experts believe the tests could save costs by reducing unnecessary chemotherapy treatments. Patient testimonials highlight the relief and informed decision-making these tests provide, especially for those concerned about the impact of chemotherapy on their quality of life and ability to care for their families.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy over the past nine years, with HMS Ocean recording five such incidents. At least one evacuation occurred on HMS Illustrious, which was nicknamed "HMS Lusty." Eighteen other ships also experienced similar emergencies. The Ministry of Defence enforces a strict "no touching" rule at sea, implying conception likely occurred before deployment or during leave. In a related incident, Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK amid allegations of an inappropriate relationship with a crew member. Since 1990, women have served on Royal Navy ships, comprising about 9% of personnel in 2014. Additionally, nearly 100 female British soldiers were evacuated from Afghanistan due to pregnancy between 2006 and 2013, with strict rules prohibiting pregnant women from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of Japan's Prime Minister's residence, raising concerns about potential terrorism. This incident coincided with a Japanese court approving the restart of two nuclear reactors, a decision unpopular due to safety fears following the Fukushima disaster. The drone, equipped with a camera and smoke flares, did not pose immediate health risks but prompted discussions on drone regulation and security measures, especially in light of upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Current laws lack specific restrictions on drone flights over government buildings in Tokyo.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang Province, China, has gained widespread admiration for his dedication to his 84-year-old mother who suffers from Alzheimer's disease. Every day, he takes her to work on the back of his motorbike, tying a sash around both of them to ensure her safety. This decision was made after his father's death, as his wife works in another city and his son is in school, leaving no one to care for his mother. Lu wakes up at 5 AM to prepare for the hour-long, four-kilometer journey to his workplace, where his employers have provided a room for his mother. He frequently checks on her during work hours to prevent her from wandering off. Lu emphasizes the reciprocal nature of care, reflecting on how his mother cared for him and his siblings when they were young, and now it is his turn to care for her.

A major study published in the American Journal of Public Health reveals that heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, with a significant rise in women's drinking habits. The study defines heavy drinking as more than one drink per day for women and two for men, and binge drinking as consuming four or more drinks for women and five for men in a single occasion. Women's binge drinking rates increased more than seven times faster than men's. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. The study attributes this trend to changing social norms, affordability of alcohol, increased advertising, and relaxed alcohol control policies. Despite these increases, the overall percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained stable. The impact of this trend includes a significant number of alcohol-related deaths and high economic costs.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too frequently, which unnecessarily endangers the health of women and their babies. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that caesarean sections should only be performed when medically necessary, estimating the ideal rate to be between 10% and 15%. Currently, over a quarter of births in England are via caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. This increase includes a growing number of women choosing planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural childbirth. The WHO emphasizes that while caesarean sections can be life-saving, they also pose significant health risks and financial burdens, with potential complications including infections, disability, or death, and higher costs for healthcare systems. The current NHS guidelines, which allow for caesareans based on maternal anxiety, contrast with the WHO's stance, highlighting the need for a reassessment of the practice.

Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 for breaking into a summer home in Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, where she lived for at least a week. She was found by the homeowner, Mark Conklin, who confronted her as she sat in his living room. Filkins claimed ownership of the house before fleeing but was later apprehended. She is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. During her stay, she allegedly held a yard sale, selling or giving away items from the home, which included furniture, kitchenware, and a painting. Police have requested that anyone who received items from the home return them to the Edgartown Police Department. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was returned to her after Albury police, located on the NSW-Victoria border, posted humorous photos and messages on her Facebook page. The phone was found and handed to the police station on Sunday morning. Realizing the phone was unlocked, the officers posted selfies and jokes on Bella's Facebook, informing her that her phone was at the station and suggesting she secure it with a password. Bella had lost her phone at a friend’s birthday party the previous night and only learned about the posts when she arrived at the station. Her friends and the police engaged in playful exchanges, praising the officers' creative approach. Bella retrieved her phone without needing to provide identification, as the officers recognized her from her Facebook profile. She appreciated the humor and has since secured her phone with a password.

A five-day-old hippopotamus calf was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in Isimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged through the water, with its mother watching helplessly. The mother had stayed with her herd during the fight, likely to avoid danger, but this decision led to the calf's death. A tour operator, Stacey Farrell, witnessed the tragic event and recounted that the mother tried to protect her baby but was unsuccessful. The calf died from its injuries hours after the incident.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, one of Britain's most expensive areas, is on the market for £575,000, significantly below the typical price for similar properties. However, the property comes with a 3-year lease, after which the buyer would need to pay a substantial amount to extend it, potentially making the property worth over £6 million. The flat, located in Egerton Place, is described as needing modernization and includes features such as a communal garden and parking. Estate agents report high interest despite the property's unique challenges.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores across the US and Canada, leading to a situation where baristas gave away free drinks and baked goods due to the inability to process payments. The issue started in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast. Despite the disruption, Starbucks managed to resolve the problem by late Friday night, and stores were set to resume normal operations on Saturday. The company apologized for the inconvenience and noted that the outage also impacted Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. Social media played a significant role in spreading the news of the free giveaways, with many customers expressing their delight and sharing photos of their free drinks. However, some stores reportedly closed early to avoid giving away more free products. This technical issue occurred just a day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings.

The passage details the use of rural areas in West Wales, specifically Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, for terrorist training and radicalization activities. Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit highlighted that individuals involved in these activities often blend into the community while harboring extremist intentions. The region's history with extremist activities dates back to 1998, involving incidents linked to Abu Hamza and the Brecon Beacons. Notably, the area has connections to the 7/7 bombers and a plot inspired by Al-Qaeda. Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, also had ties to the region through his studies at the European Institute of Human Sciences. DC Jones emphasized the importance of community vigilance in combating these threats.

An Omura's whale, a species feared extinct and only scientifically described in 2003, was found on a remote beach in Western Australia, marking the first sighting in the state and the second in Australia. The juvenile female, 5.68 meters long, was identified through DNA profiling after initial difficulties. This discovery is significant for scientists due to the limited knowledge about the species, which typically inhabits tropical and subtropical waters near Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body and distinct skeletal features, such as 53 vertebrae. The carcass has been buried, with plans to recover the skeleton for further study and potential museum display.

The passage discusses the controversial viewpoint that a woman's hormones make her unsuitable for the presidency, as expressed by Cheryl Rios, a businesswoman. Rios argues that women's hormones could lead to irrational decisions, such as starting wars. However, the author counters this by pointing out that historically, male leaders have often made poor decisions influenced by their own hormones. The passage also highlights the broader issue of gender bias in leadership roles, noting that despite women's increasing presence in education and the workforce, biases still prevent them from reaching top positions. The author emphasizes the benefits of gender equality in various aspects of society, including economic performance, family well-being, and team productivity. The piece concludes by urging a change in societal attitudes towards women's capabilities and leadership potential.

Robert Hardy, a veteran actor known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, is auctioning over 200 items from his extensive antique collection, estimated to be worth £100,000. The 89-year-old, a military historian and expert on medieval longbows, is downsizing his home. Notable items include a hand-painted diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow, and various historical artifacts and artworks. The auction, conducted by Dominic Winter Auctioneers, includes furniture, paintings, and rare books, and is scheduled to take place in Gloucestershire. Despite the sadness of parting with his collection, Hardy hopes the new owners will enjoy the items as much as he did. His career spans from Shakespearean roles to modern appearances in the Harry Potter films, where he played Cornelius Fudge.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, who was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden, Florida. Shemansky came under suspicion after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother's body was discovered. The police were alerted by an out-of-state family member who requested a welfare check. Shemansky, who is on parole for battery on a law enforcement officer and has a history of bipolar disorder and a prior suicide attempt, is believed to be on the run. Neighbors suggest that his mother may have prevented him from attending the visit, possibly due to ongoing legal issues, which might have contributed to the incident. The police have the murder weapon but have not disclosed details about it or the method of killing. Shemansky was last seen at a trailer park office asking for water and then fleeing on foot without supplies or medication. His estranged wife, who has a domestic violence injunction against him, is taking precautions. Authorities urge anyone with information to contact them.

Eugene, a city in the United States, has been selected to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The IAAF Council bypassed the standard bidding process due to the unique strategic opportunity it presented, marking the first time the event will be hosted in the USA. Eugene had previously lost its bid for the 2019 championships to Doha, Qatar. The decision was influenced by strong support from various sectors including public authorities, the private sector, the National Olympic Committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic local community. IAAF President Lamine Diack emphasized the strategic importance of this decision for the global growth of athletics.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model and care assistant, befriended Mehmet Hassan, a 56-year-old professional gambler, after seeing him with a large amount of cash at a London casino. She used her relationship with him to facilitate a robbery and murder planned by her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler. After spending an evening with Hassan, Granger left his flat, allowing Jackson and Chandler to enter, tie up Hassan, and brutally beat him to death while searching for his gambling winnings. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter and sentenced to 16 years in prison, while Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and received life sentences with a minimum term of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked," emphasizing the brutality and lack of compassion shown by the perpetrators.

Cesc Fabregas, Chelsea's midfielder, has shown a significant decline in performance during the latter part of the season, a trend noted both at club and international levels. Despite a strong start, his form has dipped, affecting his chances of breaking the Premier League record for assists. Fabregas' recent poor performance was evident in Spain’s 2-0 loss to Holland, where he received low ratings. This decline raises concerns about his stamina and impact, especially as Chelsea aims to secure the Premier League title. Manager Jose Mourinho hopes for a resurgence in Fabregas' form to aid the team's championship push.

West Ham United is in talks to sign Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old talent from Montego Bay United, who has been impressing during a trial with the club's academy. Beckford, considered one of the top young players from the Caribbean, has also received interest from Belgian clubs and other European teams. Additionally, West Ham has announced that season tickets for their new Olympic Stadium will start at £289, aiming to offer the most affordable prices in the Premier League to help fill the 54,000-seat venue.

The passage describes an assault on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, by masked protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, despite the hunt only chasing an artificial scent. The attack occurred on January 24, leaving Lane hospitalized with injuries including concussion and broken teeth. Despite receiving a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers of saboteurs, and a video capturing the incident, Wiltshire Police have decided to drop the investigation due to insufficient evidence. This decision has been met with strong criticism from Lane and other hunt supporters, who feel let down by the police's handling of the case. The Countryside Alliance is advocating for a ban on saboteurs wearing face coverings to aid in identifying and prosecuting such crimes.

Adam Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was a U.S. citizen who became a prominent figure in Al Qaeda, serving as the organization's chief English-language propagandist. Born in 1978, he converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998, where he joined Al Qaeda. He featured in numerous videos threatening Western targets and criticizing U.S. presidents. In 2006, he was indicted for treason and material support to Al Qaeda. Gadahn was killed in January during a U.S. counterterrorism operation, though he was not the specific target. His death was announced by the White House alongside the news of two hostages, Warren Weinstein and Giovanni Lo Porto, who died in a separate operation targeting another U.S. citizen, Ahmed Farouq.

The passage describes the emergence of a five-year-old Chinese basketball prodigy named Mai Zizhuo, whose advanced skills are showcased in a viral video. The video displays his ability to score multiple baskets and dribble two balls simultaneously, drawing admiration and astonishment from viewers across China. His talents have garnered significant attention, with many netizens expressing amazement and some even questioning the authenticity of the video. This phenomenon reflects the strong cultural emphasis in China on nurturing exceptionally talented children, a trend previously highlighted by the success of NBA player Yao Ming.

Tom O'Carroll, a former activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals," attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. This news is likely to be embarrassing for Hacked Off, especially since the group campaigns against the Independent Press Standards Organisation and seeks a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. PIE had previously allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), lobbying to lower the age of sexual consent to ten and to legalize incest. O'Carroll was part of the NCCL’s gay rights sub-committee.

The Icebergs Club pool in Bondi was temporarily drained to serve as a unique catwalk for a fashion show during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event featured a capsule collection by Ten Pieces, a unisex clothing line that can be styled in 20 different ways. The show, led by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased monochrome, androgynous designs with models walking through the empty pool and along the break wall, set against the ocean backdrop. Attendees enjoyed food and drinks while experiencing the fashion presentation under clear skies and warm weather, attracting attention from beachgoers and passers-by.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, took his family on a trip to Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California, where they interacted with various animals including a rare white tiger and giraffes. Khan, aged 28, was accompanied by his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and their daughter Lamysa. Additionally, Khan recently announced that he will fight Chris Algieri on May 30, opting against other potential opponents like Kell Brook, Adrien Broner, and Keith Thurman.

The passage describes a controversy over the inclusion of Mohammed Abu Khdeir's name on an Israeli memorial wall at Mount Herzl, which commemorates fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian, was murdered by three Israelis in July. His family and the organization Almagor opposed his inclusion, arguing that his death was a criminal act rather than a terrorist incident. Following complaints, particularly from his father and Almagor, the National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove his name from the memorial.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, captured a video of his young son attempting to use their family cat as a pillow outdoors. The child repeatedly follows the cat, lying down beside it whenever the cat finds a new spot, but the cat eventually walks away inside the house, tired of the game. In a subsequent video, the boy and the cat are shown reconciled, with the child feeding the cat treats.

In a Philadelphia police corruption trial, witness Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer, has lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past involvement in selling marijuana. Kushner, 32, claimed that undercover officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest, which was previously unknown to his employers. Despite passing a background check in 2010, Kushner's history of arrests, including a 2011 probation sentence and a 2008 DUI, led to his dismissal. He maintains his innocence regarding the 2011 charges and expresses regret for his past actions. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of various crimes, with their defense arguing that the prosecution relies on unreliable witnesses.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China, caused a large fire and injured six people, with five requiring hospitalization for injuries from broken glass. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a chemical used in polyester production and considered potentially carcinogenic. The explosion, resulting from an oil leak, did not lead to a toxic chemical spill. Over 600 firefighters controlled the fire. This incident follows a previous explosion at the same plant in July 2013, which had no reported casualties or toxic leaks. The plant's original planned location in Xiamen faced public opposition due to environmental concerns, leading to its relocation to a less populated area. The construction of PX plants has been a source of protest in various Chinese cities.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa player and Republic of Ireland Under-21 international, is known for his distinctive style of wearing his socks low and using children's shinpads, a practice rooted in superstition. Despite receiving comments from referees to adjust his attire, Grealish remains committed to maintaining this tradition. He made his Premier League starting debut in a 3-3 draw against QPR, expressing both the challenge and significance of the opportunity, and his desire to earn more starts based on his manager’s confidence in him.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, Bobbi Kristina remains unresponsive and does not react to visitors or familiar voices. She has a tracheostomy and her condition has not changed significantly over the past three months. While her father, Bobby Brown, recently stated that she was awake and watching him, her legal representative clarified that while her condition has improved, the quality of her future life is uncertain and she is beginning a long and challenging rehabilitation process.

Russia is leading Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup tie, putting them on the verge of reaching the final. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova secured the second point for Russia by defeating Sabine Lisicki in a tough match, saving a match point in the second set. Svetlana Kuznetsova won the first match against Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both matches featured significant serving issues, with Pavlyuchenkova committing 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors. Russia needs just one more win from Sunday's three matches to secure a place in the final, aiming for their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, still recovering from last week's severe weather, are facing warnings of another storm expected to bring heavy rain and potential flooding from Thursday. The impending weather system, an east coast low, is similar to the one that caused extensive damage last week, leaving the State Emergency Service (SES) with over 4,000 outstanding assistance requests out of 24,196 received. The SES is particularly concerned about the Hunter region, which was heavily impacted by the previous storm, and is urging residents to prepare for further potential devastation. Meteorologists predict the worst of the weather will affect the northern parts of the state, though it is expected to move more quickly than the previous system. The Bureau of Meteorology warns that catchments already affected by recent flooding may see increased rainfall, and while the severity of the upcoming weather is yet to be determined, preparations are underway to mitigate potential impacts.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model known for appearing in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" music video, denied attempting suicide after Italian media reported she was found by her mother in their Milan apartment. Moric posted on Instagram, where she has over 40,000 followers, photos of her bruised arms and stated she was hospitalized due to a fall caused by low blood pressure. She clarified that her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, was not present when the incident occurred, contradicting his statement to the press. Moric assured her fans she was recovering at home and was fine, dismissing the media reports as incorrect. She also mentioned her past marriage to paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son, Carlos Maria, born in 2002. Corona, known as the 'king' of Italy’s paparazzi, served jail time for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photos.

The British public, through a YouGov poll for The Sunday Times, shows a preference for traditional names for Kate and William's second child, with "Diana" leading at 12% for a girl, honoring Princess Diana. Alice and Charlotte follow at 9% each, reflecting connections to the royal family. For a boy, James leads at 13%, followed by Alexander. A quarter of the 2,200 respondents hope for a princess, contrasting with only 3% wanting a prince. Social media reflects strong support for the name Diana, and 68% back William’s decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bombing occurred in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, during a protest, resulting in 17 deaths and 64 injuries, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack happened around 10 a.m. local time as protesters were heading to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied involvement, and no other group has claimed responsibility for the attack.

Dani Alves, the Brazilian right-back, is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Despite seven successful years at the club, including four Spanish titles and two Champions League victories, Alves and his representatives could not agree on a new deal. His agent, Dinorah Santana, stated that the negotiations are over as the offered three-year contract extension was contingent on Alves playing in 60% of the matches, a condition deemed unsatisfactory.

Pablo Osvaldo, who recently joined Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton and has quickly made an impact, is encouraging Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the club. Osvaldo believes that both players, known for their exceptional skills and South American playing style, would fit well at Boca Juniors and would be adored by the fans at La Bombonera stadium. He emphasizes that such a move would be beneficial for both the players and the club.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, experienced a dramatic double somersault fall from his horse during a race at Wincanton, which became an internet sensation. Despite the severity of the fall, captured in a video viewed by hundreds of thousands online, Ferguson only sustained a minor cut on his nose. He returned to his routine at Paul Nicholls's yard, continuing to muck out stables and ride out, showing no signs of being deterred. Ferguson mentioned receiving support from fellow jockeys and gaining new social media followers, taking the incident in stride with humor, even joking about a potential future in gymnastics.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain and England flanker, posted an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man from the "Avengers: Age of Ultron" movie, which premiered at Westfield London Shopping Centre. The movie features a star-studded cast including Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell's post included hashtags related to the movie and his transformation. Additionally, the passage provides background on Haskell’s career, noting his return to Wasps in 2012 after playing for teams in France, Japan, and New Zealand. Since rejoining Wasps, Haskell has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and has earned 57 caps for England.

The passage discusses the resurgence of wide leg trousers as a fashion trend for Spring/Summer 2015. These trousers, available in various styles such as denim, cropped, printed, or striped, offer a comfortable and stylish alternative to skinny jeans. Celebrities like Louise Redknapp and Emma endorse the trend, noting its appeal after years of skinny jeans dominating fashion. The key to styling wide leg trousers, especially for those who are shorter, is to balance the volume with high-heeled shoes and simple tops. Denim is highlighted as the most accessible way to incorporate this trend, with designer brands like Gucci and Topshop offering their versions. The trend is versatile, suitable for both casual and evening wear, and can be adapted with different accessories to maintain a modern look.

The University of Michigan initially faced a petition from over 200 students requesting the cancellation of a planned screening of "American Sniper" due to concerns about its negative portrayal of the Middle East and its people. The university's decision to cancel the screening was met with a counter-petition and criticism, leading to a reversal of the decision. E. Royster Harper, the university's Vice President for Student Life, acknowledged the mistake in cancelling the film, emphasizing the university's commitment to freedom of expression. As an alternative, the university will also screen the family-friendly film "Paddington" for those preferring not to watch "American Sniper."

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, attempted to set a quokka on fire using an aerosol spray and a lighter on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka, a cat-sized marsupial native to the area, survived but was singed. The men were questioned, evicted from the island, and charged with animal cruelty; they are due to appear in court on April 17.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer from the 1930s and 1940s, who performed at venues like the Cotton Club, recently got to see herself dance for the first time thanks to filmmakers. Despite having been part of performances with famous figures such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra, Barker had lost all her photographs and memorabilia over the years and had never seen footage of herself. Mark Cantor and his team compiled a video of "soundies," early music videos, which they showed to Barker at her nursing home, bringing her great joy.

The passage discusses the declining trend of people washing their own cars in Britain, a task that was once a common Sunday activity. According to a study by vehicle leasing firm OSV, a third of men and three-quarters of women have never washed their own car, with many opting for car wash services instead. Factors contributing to this shift include the availability of hand car washes, larger vehicle sizes, and alternative weekend activities like shopping and watching sports. The tradition is more prevalent in cities like Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and less so in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Owners of Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are more likely to wash their cars themselves compared to those who own Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes.

Martin Skrtel praises Steven Gerrard's significant impact on him since joining Liverpool in 2008, considering Gerrard one of the best players in the world and a symbol of the club. Despite the challenge of replacing Gerrard, Skrtel believes Liverpool has the potential to manage the transition successfully. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, potentially leading to a final on his birthday, May 30, before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel highlights Gerrard’s supportive role in helping him settle at Liverpool and expresses confidence in the team's ability to support potential replacements for Gerrard.

At age 75, Jack Nicklaus, often considered the greatest golfer of all time, made a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. This occurred on the 130-yard fourth hole, delighting the crowd and his playing partners, Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Nicklaus's achievement, however, was part of a record-tying day for aces, with Camilo Villegas also making two holes-in-one but losing the contest in a playoff to Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus, who has won six green jackets and is among the few to have completed the career Grand Slam, remains a significant figure in golf history.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night due to multiple storms, with confirmed tornado sightings near Goddard and Aetna. The storms posed significant risks, especially at night, which increases danger. Missouri also experienced severe weather, with possible tornado damage in Potosi, including wind damage and flooding. Baseball-sized hail was reported in Farmington. The National Weather Service forecasted continued storm activity for Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old reserve deputy sheriff in Oklahoma, pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree manslaughter for the fatal shooting of Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation. Bates claims the shooting was accidental, stating he intended to use a taser but mistakenly used his gun. The judge allowed Bates to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation, which upset Harris's family, who perceived it as insensitive. The family's lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff. The sheriff’s office denies these allegations. Bates' preliminary hearing is set for July 2. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irish fighter, is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11. He recently got a new tattoo of a tiger's face on his stomach, adding to his existing gorilla tattoo on his chest. McGregor believes the tattoo symbolizes that "if you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor is highly motivated for the fight, claiming that Aldo, who is defending his title for the eighth time, lacks the same level of desire. During a promotional event in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo’s belt in front of 5,000 fans, further intensifying their rivalry.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after he quickly drank a beer (skolled) at an Australian rules function. Critics argue that his actions promote binge drinking and associate masculinity with heavy alcohol consumption, potentially setting a negative cultural precedent. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert expressed concern over the message this sends about drinking culture, emphasizing that it shifts focus from socializing to competitive drinking. Despite the backlash, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, highlighting his active lifestyle and fitness. The incident has sparked discussions about responsible drinking and the role of public figures in influencing societal norms.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases, rising to 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases, primarily linked to intravenous drug use in Scott County. This surge prompted Governor Mike Pence to approve a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26, despite his general opposition to such programs. Since its implementation, over 5,300 clean syringes have been distributed, and about 1,400 used syringes have been returned. Health officials anticipate further increases in HIV cases as more individuals are tested. The effectiveness and future of the program, along with related legislation, remain uncertain due to concerns about promoting drug use and financial sustainability.

An Arsenal FC fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a detailed quiz about the football club to test her knowledge. The test was formatted like a school exam, complete with multiple-choice questions, tables to fill out, and instructions to read questions carefully. Despite finding the situation humorous and challenging, Saskia scored 87% (43.5 out of 50). Her boyfriend was pleased with her performance, giving her an 'A' grade and deciding not to break up with her. The boyfriend's actions received mixed reactions online; while some praised him as a "legend" and others found the idea amusing, a few criticized him for being overzealous. Many male Twitter users expressed interest in testing their own girlfriends' knowledge of their favorite teams.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as an informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of U.S. citizenship. After retiring due to declining health, Toro now faces deportation, despite his significant contributions, which included aiding in the takedown of major figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. The DEA has not assisted Toro with his citizenship, leaving him in legal limbo and fearing for his life should he return to Colombia. His situation highlights issues with government bureaucracy and the treatment of informants post-retirement.

A 14-year-old girl in India allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village set herself on fire, suffering 70% burns. She is currently hospitalized in Delhi. The incident occurred in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, when she went outside her home. Her brother extinguished the flames, and the accused men have since been arrested. This event has heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following the ban of a documentary "India's Daughter" about a previous high-profile gang rape case in Delhi. Recent attacks have led to protests demanding better protection for women, and there have been instances of vigilante justice.

Manchester United's manager, Louis van Gaal, expresses his desire to beat rivals Manchester City in the upcoming derby at Old Trafford, aiming to secure a higher league position, possibly as high as third. However, he confirms that Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw will not play due to not being fit enough, despite Van Persie claiming he is ready. Van Gaal emphasizes the importance of controlling aggression during the match and acknowledges the challenge posed by City, who recently suffered a defeat. He also praises the support of Manchester United fans and looks forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere at home for the first time since joining the club.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of a Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest was sparked by the recent £5.14 billion TV rights deal, which fans believe should lead to lower ticket prices rather than the current high costs, with tickets starting at £64. Fans displayed banners both inside and outside the stadium, emphasizing their dissatisfaction with the pricing and the impact on their ability to attend matches. Organizers from fan groups like Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool’s Spirit of Shankly called for solidarity among fans and tangible reductions in ticket prices to ensure the sport remains accessible to working-class supporters.

A newborn baby named Star, diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, required a liver transplant. Neither of her parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, were suitable matches, but her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, offered part of her liver. The transplant was successful, and Star has since made a good recovery, though she requires regular medical check-ups and lifelong anti-rejection medication. Biliary atresia is a rare condition affecting about 1 in 16,000 babies, characterized by blocked or absent bile ducts, leading to jaundice and potentially liver failure if untreated.

Chelsea players, including Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian, participated in Audi's Football Challenge, a series of games involving shooting balls into cars. Hazard and Ake won the initial rounds, scoring points by successfully aiming balls into a car's boot and over an Audi R8 V10 Plus used as a net. However, Remy and Willian won the final challenge, which involved long-range shots at convertibles. Notably, Willian accidentally broke a wing mirror during the event, causing a humorous moment captured in the video.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, was involved in a fatal car accident in December 2013, which killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy (24) and Jason Timmons (29), along with their unborn child. Initially, Dellinger told investigators he was attempting suicide, but during his sentencing, he denied these claims, stating he has "never been suicidal." His lawyers argue that Dellinger's actions were influenced by Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and symptoms of multiple sclerosis. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. The case also includes a wrongful death lawsuit filed by Amanda Murphy’s estate.

Lacey Spears, from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her 5-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, whom she poisoned with salt. The boy’s father, Chris Hill, expressed intense anger and lack of sympathy towards Spears on Facebook, hoping for harsh treatment of her in prison. The judge acknowledged Spears' mental illness but deemed the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty." Prosecutors argued that Spears fabricated her son’s illnesses for attention, leading to his unnecessary suffering and eventual death. Her defense team plans to appeal the verdict, maintaining her innocence and blaming hospital negligence.

An improved influenza vaccine, designed to combat two new strains (H3N2 and B/Phuket) that caused a significant increase in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States, is set to arrive in Australia a month later than anticipated. This delay is due to the inclusion of these strains in the vaccine formulation. High-risk groups, including young children, the elderly, and Indigenous Australians, will have access to free, government-funded flu shots starting April 20. Experts recommend the modified vaccine, emphasizing its importance for all individuals, not just those at high risk, to help protect vulnerable populations and reduce the spread of the virus. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, stresses the effectiveness of the new vaccine and advises early booking for flu shots despite the delayed arrival of vaccine stocks.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois, are facing criticism from National Geographic, which described the site as lacking historical character, and potential budget cuts that could affect its management. The state is commemorating the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination, but Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency responsible for the tomb, merging it into another department. Despite recent renovations and maintenance, the tomb has faced reduced hours and staffing due to budget reductions. Supporters of the tomb dispute the National Geographic critique, emphasizing the site's historical significance and recent improvements.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 1990s fashion trends, focusing on items that are making a comeback despite their impracticality or questionable aesthetic appeal. Key trends highlighted include JNCO jeans, bucket hats, camouflage print, maximalist styling (such as double denim), Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes shorts, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers. The article contrasts how these items were worn in the past by celebrities like Christina Aguilera, Beyoncé, and Paris Hilton, with current fashion-forward figures like Rihanna, Jourdan Dunn, and Kylie Jenner, who are attempting to revive or maintain these trends.

The passage highlights several trending stories from a busy week online. In New York, four rainbows were spotted after heavy rainfall, captured by a fashion CEO. In China, a ban on hiring exotic dancers for funeral services reflects a broader government crackdown on vice. Actor Robert Downey Jr. became upset during a UK interview about personal questions. The Kardashians introduced a new trend called the "Kylie Jenner challenge," involving lip plumping. A 102-year-old woman revisited her past with the help of filmmakers. A high school controversy arose over a prom proposal referencing bombs, with accusations of racism. Ewan McGregor's casting as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast" drew social media attention. Johnny Depp's transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer was notable. Creative pregnancy announcements, including one referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military father's surprise appearance in his son's photo were also highlighted.

Serena Williams achieved her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, advancing to the semi-finals after defeating Sabine Lisicki in a three-set match. The tournament has become known for celebrating players' milestone wins with large cakes, as seen the previous day when Andy Murray celebrated his 500th win. Venus Williams was eliminated from the tournament by Carla Suarez Navarro, ending the possibility of a sisters' matchup. Serena's next opponent in the semi-finals will be Simona Halep, who defeated Sloane Stephens.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent advocate for free speech and human rights in Pakistan, ran a second-floor café called T2F, which served as a hub for discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. Despite receiving death threats, she continued to organize events, including a controversial discussion on the situation in Baluchistan, which many wanted silenced. On April 24, 2015, she was shot dead by two gunmen after closing the café for the night. Her mother, who was also shot, survived. No one claimed responsibility for the attack, but it highlighted the dangers of free speech in Pakistan. Mahmud was widely mourned as a symbol of bravery and progressivism, and her death sparked widespread grief and tributes on social media.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer, is among thousands of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) who fled to Indian Kashmir during the 1947 partition. Despite living in India for nearly 70 years, these refugees are still considered second-class citizens, unable to own property or vote in state elections. This status has trapped multiple generations in poverty. However, with the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) gaining power in the region, there is renewed hope that WPRs might finally gain full citizenship rights. The BJP has pledged to normalize the status of WPRs, potentially improving their socio-economic conditions. The issue is complex, influenced by the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state and the ongoing conflict over Kashmir.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is contemplating a move to Chelsea, who have reportedly offered around £4 million for him. Muto, aged 22, is concerned about playing regularly and developing his potential, which might influence his decision. Real Zaragoza's former coach, Ranko Popovic, praises Muto's unique qualities and potential, suggesting he could succeed at Chelsea. Chelsea's interest in Muto may also be influenced by their commercial ties with Japan, including a significant sponsorship deal. However, Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho emphasizes that any signing must align with both commercial interests and the team's need for quality players.

The passage discusses the policy changes in international rugby, specifically praising Australia for reversing its stance against selecting players based on their overseas status. It criticizes England's rigid policy, suggesting that England's national team should prioritize selecting the best players regardless of where they play. The author argues that playing abroad can improve a player's skills, citing examples like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon. The emphasis is on maximizing the team's potential for the World Cup, emphasizing that the best team composition is crucial for success, especially for the host nation. The passage concludes by commending Australia's decision and urging England to reconsider its approach.

The FireChat app, developed by Open Garden, enables users to communicate without internet or mobile signals through wireless mesh networks. This technology leverages Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework and Android's Bluetooth capabilities to create localized networks where phones act as nodes, passing data between them. FireChat has seen significant adoption, with over five million downloads, and is particularly useful in areas with limited connectivity, such as planes or underground.

To enhance the range and reliability of these mesh networks, Open Garden has introduced Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that acts as a booster. Greenstone extends the reach of messages beyond the typical 200 feet limit of direct phone-to-phone communication. It can store up to 1,000 recent messages and has a battery life of one year. The device is envisioned to support various scenarios, including large gatherings like music festivals or protests, where network congestion is common. Greenstone is currently in development and is expected to integrate seamlessly with FireChat, though its availability depends on manufacturing partnerships.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is working to change the negative connotations associated with the term "fat" by embracing it as a positive descriptor of her own body. During a TED Talk, she discussed how societal pressures often make women avoid being called "fat," equating it with ugliness. Lillian argues that exposure to diverse body types can increase acceptance and appreciation of different physiques. She shared her personal journey into burlesque, which has been empowering and has helped her overcome insecurities. Despite some negative reactions, her TED Talk has received widespread positive feedback, reinforcing her belief in the power of body positivity.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, has been frequently left out of the starting lineup this season, often seen on the bench. Despite this, he participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, the club's official tailor since 2013, alongside six of his teammates: Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil. The photoshoot included runway model Olga Sherer and was part of the club’s partnership with the Parisian fashion house. Walcott has been named on the substitutes' bench for 17 of Arsenal's 33 Barclays Premier League games and recently played the last six minutes in a draw against Chelsea. He is hoping to start in the upcoming match against Hull City, his first potential start since March 14.

A collection of movie props and puppets created by renowned makeup effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online at Propstore.com. The collection, estimated to be worth $746,100, includes over 400 items from more than 50 productions, spanning Baker's 30-year career. Notable items include the Alien Edgar Bug from "Men in Black" (valued at $40,000), the Two-Face mask from "Batman Forever" ($1,500), and the Grinch costume from "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" ($8,000). Other films represented include "An American Werewolf in London," "Planet of the Apes," "Batman & Robin," "Hellboy," and "Mighty Joe Young." Brandon Alinger of Prop Store emphasized the significance of the auction, highlighting it as a unique opportunity for collectors and fans to own pieces from their favorite films.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, died in a skiing accident in the French Alps. He was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined child who was a competent skier. During a family ski trip, Carwyn became separated from his mother and siblings, ventured into dense woodland, and tragically fell over a 164-foot drop. His mother, Carri, desperately searched for him, and his footprints in the snow eventually led to his body. The family, known for their award-winning farm shop, expressed deep sorrow, stating that his death left a vast void in their hearts. Carwyn's school and local community are mourning his loss, with tributes highlighting his lively and likeable nature.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 due to societal pressures to be a "size zero." Her condition worsened to the point where she was consuming only about 100 calories a day, leading to her body shutting down and requiring hospitalization. After a week on a heart monitor, Laura received support from eating disorder organizations and began her recovery. She now speaks out against the pressures on young girls to conform to unrealistic body standards and has gained enough confidence to reach the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive body image.

Raheem Sterling, along with other Liverpool players, unveiled the club's new home kit designed by New Balance, amid strong messages from fans urging him to stay at the club. The kit launch, which took place at Anfield, marked New Balance’s first design for Liverpool under a record-breaking £300 million, four-year deal. Despite recent speculation about Sterling's future, including his rejection of a £100,000-a-week contract and links to Arsenal, Liverpool remains confident he will stay. The event also highlighted the team's focus on the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with players expressing their enthusiasm for the match and the support of the fans.

A team from the University of Manchester, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, has created the largest high-definition map of dark matter to date, covering 0.4% of the sky. This map is part of the Dark Energy Survey (DES), a five-year project aiming to map 12.5% of the sky, providing a 3D view of dark matter. The map, constructed using data from the Dark Energy Camera, reveals areas of dense and sparse dark matter, indicated by red and blue respectively. Dark matter, which constitutes about 85% of the universe's matter, is inferred through its gravitational effects on visible matter. The DES uses gravitational lensing to detect dark matter, observing how it distorts light from distant galaxies. This research helps in understanding the formation of galaxies and testing cosmological theories, suggesting that galaxies form in regions with higher concentrations of dark matter. The survey, now in its second year, aims to complete its mapping by 2018, enhancing our knowledge of dark matter and dark energy.

Manchester United has made an official bid to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old star, Memphis Depay, with United's manager Louis van Gaal, who previously coached Depay during the 2014 World Cup, keen on securing his transfer. Depay, known for his speed and dribbling skills, has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, contributing significantly to PSV's first Dutch championship in seven years. Despite interest from other major European clubs, including Paris-Saint Germain, Manchester United is reportedly in a strong position to sign him. PSV's technical director, Marcel Brands, confirmed the interest and noted that any deal would involve a higher fee than the £15 million rejected by PSV from Tottenham last summer.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's young side in the Youth Cup Final, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. The match showcased promising performances from both teams' young talents, including Abraham, who has now scored 36 goals this season, and Manchester City's Bradley Barker, who is tipped for a bright future. Chelsea's defense, led by Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, was particularly strong, while Isaiah Brown and Charlie Colkett also stood out for Chelsea. Despite the loss, City's players, such as Tosin Adarabioyo and Kean Bryan, demonstrated resilience and skill.

Marco Rubio, a Florida senator and presidential candidate, asserts that people are born with a sexual preference and maintains that states, not federal courts, should decide on the legality of same-sex marriage. He clarified his stance by stating that while he personally supports the traditional definition of marriage as between one man and one woman, he would attend a same-sex wedding of a loved one or staff member despite his personal beliefs. Rubio emphasizes that marriage laws should be determined through state legislatures and political debates, not judicial decisions, and he does not consider same-sex marriage a constitutional right. Additionally, he mentioned his Catholic faith's stance against divorce but assured that he would still support a loved one who divorces.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish and Latvian couple respectively, embarked on a global cycling journey with the simple goal of exploring the world "a pedal at a time." After quitting their jobs in Manchester, they began their adventure, living frugally on less than three euros a day each. In nearly a year, they have cycled approximately 7,000 miles through 16 countries, primarily camping or staying with hosts through platforms like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers. Their diet consists mainly of affordable staples and occasional free meals or wild foods. Starting from London, they have traveled through Western and Eastern Europe, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, with plans to continue into Asia and eventually cross the Pacific to cycle through the Americas.

A Texas couple, who got married in 2012, are suing James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing a racial slur, "poor n***** party," on the bottom of their photo booth pictures. The slur was discovered months after the wedding by the bride's sister, who initially kept quiet to avoid spoiling the bride’s special day. Upon learning about the incident, the groom contacted Evans, who reportedly responded with "sue me" instead of apologizing. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies all allegations, stating there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption and noting the couple showed no signs of mental distress. Mediation is scheduled, but if unresolved, the case will go to trial in July. The couple primarily seeks an apology.

Mike Brown, England's full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recover from a recent concussion, unsure of his return date after withdrawing from a match. He emphasizes the importance of recognizing concussion symptoms, attributing his awareness to World Rugby online modules. Brown highlights the risks of rushing recovery, citing cases like George North and Johnny Sexton, who faced extended breaks due to multiple concussions. He stresses the significance of honesty and caution in dealing with head injuries, even if it means missing crucial games.

Professor David Spiegelhalter from Cambridge University suggests that smartphone use and the integration of public and private life due to technology might be contributing to a decline in sexual activity among couples. According to his research, British couples are now having sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. The decline is attributed to increased connectivity, busier lifestyles, and the erosion of boundaries between work and home life, which reduces the time and focus available for intimate relationships. Catherine Mercer, a researcher, adds that competing demands on time and constant connection to work and the outside world through technology can push sex down the priority list.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once highly valued in China with prices reaching up to £1.2 million, are now facing a severe decline in popularity. This shift is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption campaign, which has curtailed the practice of gifting these dogs to officials. Additionally, restrictions on owning large dogs in major cities have further impacted their demand. As a result, many Tibetan Mastiffs are being sent to slaughterhouses, with some dying in transit due to poor conditions. The breed's decline is also linked to overbreeding and urbanization, making them less suitable for city life. Previously, these dogs were considered status symbols and were traditionally used in Tibet for herding.

A survey of 600 women in Paris revealed that all respondents experienced sexual harassment on public transport, with half reporting initial incidents before turning 18. The harassment spans from verbal insults to physical assaults, significantly impacting women's sense of safety and altering their daily routines to avoid confrontation. This issue restricts women’s freedom and participation in public life. The findings prompted calls for a campaign to address and penalize sexist and threatening behavior on public transport, emphasizing the need to educate both victims and bystanders about the illegality and severity of such actions.

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, organized a competition called #everydayfix to address common daily issues through innovative product designs. They surveyed 2,000 people to identify the top ten 'everyday emergencies,' with the inability to sleep topping the list. Three prototypes were shortlisted: 'Snooze,' an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to improve sleep; 'Forget Me Lock,' a device that confirms if a door is locked; and 'Nipper,' a small phone charger powered by household batteries. The public can vote on Twitter, and the winning product will proceed to Kickstarter for funding and development.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for awarding £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she directs alongside Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim. This action has sparked criticism, including accusations of a conflict of interest and inappropriateness. The controversy arises despite a new rule by the Home Secretary allowing Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs) to commission services for crime victims. Critics, such as Keith Vaz, argue that PCCs should not have the authority to allocate public funds to organizations in which they have personal interests. Baird maintains that all procedures were followed correctly. Additionally, Sim, who is retiring in June, previously faced an investigation for alleged workplace bullying, which Baird oversaw. The Ministry of Justice will investigate to determine if there was a breach of conflict of interest rules.

A 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, was brutally assaulted by a group led by Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, in Philadelphia. The attack, motivated by Campbell's belief that Valecce had harmed his cat and stolen items, involved beating, tying Valecce to a chair, and forcibly tattooing offensive images and words on his body. The incident lasted about 42 hours and resulted in severe physical injuries. Campbell and his accomplices, Sandra Ng, 19, and Carl Halin, 18, have been sentenced to prison terms ranging from 23 months to 20 years. Two other individuals, David Harrison and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting legal proceedings. Valecce has since had the tattoos removed but suffers from lasting psychological trauma.

Manchester United has made an official bid to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old star, Memphis Depay, with the club's manager, Louis van Gaal, keen on making him one of his primary signings this summer. Van Gaal previously coached Depay during the 2014 World Cup, where Holland secured third place. Despite interest from other major European clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain, Manchester United seems to be leading the race for the player. Known for his speed, dribbling skills, and goal-scoring ability, Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, contributing significantly to PSV's first Dutch championship in seven years. He has also received high praise, being compared favorably to a young Cristiano Ronaldo by a former scout for Manchester United.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's young side in the Youth Cup final, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. The match showcased promising performances from both teams' young talents, including Abraham, who has now scored 36 goals this season, and Manchester City's Bradley Barker, who is tipped for a bright future.
